Compiling CoreData C++ API

1. Compiling with Microsoft Visual Studio 2008
2. Compiling with Microsoft Visual Studio 2005
3. Compiling with Linux GCC
4. Compiling with Mac OS X GCC

1. Compiling with Microsoft Visual Studio 2008

To compile CoreData with Microsoft Visual Studio 2008:
  • Open the solution coredata.win32_ia32sse2_vc90.sln
  • Choose the build type (e.g. ReleaseStatic) using the Standard Toolbar:

  • Select "Build Solution" from the "Build" menu.
  • The output library binary will be placed in coredata\libstatic\win32_ia32sse2_vc90.
  • The output example binaries will be placed in the coredata\bin\win32_ia32sse2_vc90.

2. Compiling with Microsoft Visual Studio 2005

To compile CoreData with Microsoft Visual Studio 2005:
  • Open the solution coredata.win32_ia32sse2_vc80.sln
  • Choose the build type (e.g. ReleaseStatic) using the Standard Toolbar
  • Select "Build Solution" from the "Build" menu.
  • The output library binary will be placed in coredata\libstatic\win32_ia32sse2_vc80.
  • The output example binaries will be placed in the coredata\bin\win32_ia32sse2_vc80.

3. Compiling with Linux GCC

The provided Makefiles use the version of gcc symlinked on the system.

This release has been compiled and tested with Ubuntu 9.04 and gcc4.2.4. It may not compile with all Linux/GCC distributions.

There are 2 makefiles supplied.

  • Makefile.linux_ia32 does not enable SSE2 instructions.
  • Makefile.linux_ia32sse2 enables SSE2 instructions.

In the instructions below substitute the linux_ia32 if you are compiling for a processor without SSE2 support.

To compile the CoreData C++ API:

  • Open a shell
  • cd to the coredata/src directory.
  • Type make -f Makefile.linux_ia32sse2 clean to create the intermediate directories. This must be done at least once before making any build configurataion.
  • Type make -f Makefile.linux_ia32sse2 all to build debug and release, static and shared libraries.
  • Alternatively, you can type make -f Makefile.linux_ia32sse2 TARGET where TARGET is one of: debugstatic, releasestatic, debugshared, releaseshared.
  • The output directory for shared libraries is coredata/libshared/linux_ia32sse2, static libraries will be stored at coredata/libstatic/linux_ia32sse2.

To compile all the CoreData example applications:

  • Compile the CoreData C++ API, as described above.
  • cd to the coredata/examples directory
  • Type make -f Makefile.linux_ia32sse2 clean to create the intermediate directories. This must be done at least once before making any build configurataion.
  • Type make -f Makefile.linux_ia32sse2 all to build all applications in both debug and release build configurations.
  • Alternatively, you can type make -f Makefile.linux_ia32sse2 TARGET where TARGET is one of: debugstatic, releasestatic.
  • The output application binaries will be placed in coredata/bin/linux_ia32sse2.

To compile an individual example application:

  • Compile the CoreData C++ API, as described above.
  • cd to the desired application directory (e.g. coredata/examples/logconverter)
  • Type make -f Makefile.linux_ia32sse2 all to build both debug and release static libraries
  • Alternatively, you can type make -f Makefile.linux_ia32sse2 TARGET where TARGET is one of: debugstatic, releasestatic.
  • The output application binaries will be placed in coredata/bin/linux_ia32sse2.

4. Compiling with Mac OS X GCC

The provided Makefiles use settings appropriate for Mac OSX GCC 4.0.

This release has been compiled and tested with Mac OSX 10.4.11 and gcc4.0.1. It may not compile with all Mac OS X/GCC distributions.

To compile the CoreData C++ API:

  • Open a shell
  • cd to the coredata/src directory.
  • Type make -f Makefile.mac_ia32sse2 clean to create the intermediate directories. This must be done at least once before making any build configurataion.
  • Type make -f Makefile.mac_ia32sse2 all to build debug and release, static and shared libraries.
  • Alternatively, you can type make -f Makefile.mac_ia32sse2 TARGET where TARGET is one of: debugstatic, releasestatic, debugshared, releaseshared.
  • The output directory for shared libraries is coredata/libshared/mac_ia32sse2, static libraries will be stored at coredata/libstatic/mac_ia32sse2.

To compile all the CoreData example applications:

  • Compile the CoreData C++ API, as described above.
  • cd to the coredata/examples directory
  • Type make -f Makefile.mac_ia32sse2 clean to create the intermediate directories. This must be done at least once before making any build configurataion.
  • Type make -f Makefile.mac_ia32sse2 all to build all applications in both debug and release build configurations.
  • Alternatively, you can type make -f Makefile.mac_ia32sse2 TARGET where TARGET is one of: debugstatic, releasestatic.
  • The output application binaries will be placed in coredata/bin/mac_ia32sse2.

To compile an individual example application:

  • Compile the CoreData C++ API, as described above.
  • cd to the desired application directory (e.g. coredata/examples/logconverter)
  • Type make -f Makefile.mac_ia32sse2 all to build both debug and release static libraries
  • Alternatively, you can type make -f Makefile.mac_ia32sse2 TARGET where TARGET is one of: debugstatic, releasestatic.
  • The output application binaries will be placed in coredata/bin/mac_ia32sse2.

Note:
:
  • Precompiled headers are not currently supported on Mac OS X.
